channel.title: Posts on Adam Thompson's Lab Notebook
channel.description: Recent content in Posts on Adam Thompson's Lab Notebook

item.title: My VIM Cheatsheet
item.description: This is my ongoing Vim quick reference. Note that this is in no way meant to be an exhaustive cheatsheet for Vim. This is more a list of things I’m personally constantly forgetting how to do. Searching, Pattern Matching, and Replacing Searching for a Pattern :/pattern Find and Replace :%s/searchtext/replacetext/g Note: Leave off the /g to only replace the first match on each line. Limit the Range of Affected Lines :N,Ms/searchtext/replacetext/g Where N is the first line and M is the last line.

item.title: Handy CTF Commands
item.description: This is a collection of commands that I find useful when playing CTFs. Linux Stabilize a Reverse Shell python -c 'import pty; pty.spawn("/bin/bash")' Finding all SUID Binaries on a System find / -user root -perm -4000 -exec ls -ldb {} \; Transfer Files with Netcat On the receiving end: nc -lp 4444 > out.file On the sending end: nc -w 3 [destination IP] 4444 < out.file Windows Check the Current User Privileges whoami /privs

item.title: NMap Reference
item.description: This is my personal quick reference for working with NMap. Flag Description -sV Attempts to determine the version of the services that are running -p <x> or -p- Port scan for port <x> or scan all ports -Pn Disable host discovery and just scan for open ports -A Enables OS and version detection, executes in-build scripts for further enumeration. Aggressive Mode. -sC Scan with the default nmap script -v Verbose mode -sU UDP port scan -sS TCP SYN port scan -Pn Disable the ping scan -T5 Sets to time template level 5.

item.title: How To Delete a Git Submodule
item.description: To delete a submodule from git, do the following: Delete the relevant section from the .gitmodules file. Delete the relevant section from the .git/config file. Run git rm --cached <path_to_submodule>. Run git rm --cached <path_to_submodule>. Run rm -rf .git/modules/<path_to_submodule>. Commit the changes.

item.title: Building Serenity OS on Windows with WSL 2
item.description: I’ve been following the development of Serenity OS with a fair bit of interest for the past few months. As such, I’ve been itching to try building the system and playing around with it. I finally got a bit of time and decided that, for a bit of an extra challenge, I’d attempt to get it running through WSL 2 on Windows 10. This is something that is actually officially documented in the GitHub repository, but I ran into a few roadblocks along the way.
